When we thought boom was the same episode as the planets getting dusted, when the set leakers said the election episode was the same as the slug monsters, when we thought kastarion was gallifrey, little glimpses of monsters and sets you could never dream what the context was. It felt like the start of the next years of our life, and it hardly scraped over one. People who were there for Colin Baker, Paul McGann, I feel you now. I know what it's like to have the future road for the show paved out and then see it crumble down. But they have their fans, they have their fanworks and audios and their behind-the-scenes histories, Ncuti will get his dues and his memories, it just takes time. One day doctor who will get a team that knows nothing's "too big to fail", but for the time being, I suppose this sixty year mythos is in our hands.

Gets off to a good start, with some solid production values, as can be expected from Apple TV, but expect to get tired of the repetition the premise locks the structure into e.g. corny, 'CIA conspiracy theory exposition' scenes, interrupted by another emergency chase to save my wife and/or son and/or community from the next cheesy bad guy doing bad stuff. Probably best viewed on a one episode per weekly schedule, like in the old days, so the patterns aren't so obviously gratuitous, and on a wet winter's Wednesday night, you won't really care. One 'uplifting' set piece around Ep.5 worth looking up from your phone for, and it is a relief to have another actor other than Kiefer Sutherland doing a raspy voice. So, yeah, slightly more entertainment value than moving wallpaper.

I came across this show and I am a sucker for cop/robber shows. I finished the series but will only discuss the opener. It opens with the death of an officer on duty. Officer Harmon, her trainer, is a veteran. Her scars bear witness. She is passionate but flawed. Dutiful but will bend rules. This is communicated in the first episode with the introduction of her new rookie trainee. Officer Diaz is relentless in pursuit of his ambitions and shares the same zeal for the job as her trainer. Officer Harmon doesn't know that, yet. It grabs you the first episode if you can handle the fast pace. All around it's good cop show with a peak window look at a criminal syndicate.

Youâ€™re absolutely right to question that. A lot of these prison documentaries, especially ones like Unlocked: A Jail Experiment, tend to package familiar setups as if theyâ€™re revolutionary. Itâ€™s probably a mix of marketing hype and trying to create a narrative arc for viewers who donâ€™t have real experience with jail or prison systems.

The â€œexperimentâ€ part often boils down to tone, not actual structure. For example, in that Arkansas setup, the media might be hyping up the idea that guards are less hands-on and inmates are given more â€œfreedomâ€ or self-governanceâ€”but to someone whoâ€™s been inside, it just looks like regular day-to-day pod life. Youâ€™re still locked in, still around the same people 24/7, still following a rigid schedule.

They act like itâ€™s a privilege because, to outsiders, the idea of inmates being â€œtrustedâ€ to manage themselves sounds radical. But in reality, inmates already do that by necessity. The guards often arenâ€™t involved unless thereâ€™s a problemâ€”they arenâ€™t babysitting.

Itâ€™s like theyâ€™re repackaging something youâ€™ve lived through and calling it innovation for the sake of storytelling and ratings.

Man vs Baby is bad in a very predictable way: loud, cheap and relentlessly stressful without being funny. The problem is not just the writing, but how unreal everything is. Trevor Bingley leaves a baby unattended in a luxury penthouse, hides it in bags and cupboards, drags it through public spaces, and nothing ever has believable consequences. In one episode he uses designer scarves and random household items as makeshift baby gear, played as â€œcomedyâ€ despite being absurd and nonsensical. Entire sequences rely on instant escalation: minor mishaps turn into full-scale destruction within seconds, clearly driven by editing and sound effects rather than cause and effect. The baby itself feels uncanny, more like an AI-assisted prop than a real infant, with stiff reactions and a Chucky-like presence that pulls you out of every scene. Acting is broad and lazy, production feels bargain-basement, and every gag is visible minutes in advance. Many viewers describe the same experience: irritating, repetitive, and exhausting rather than funny. Compared to classic Mr. Bean, where physical comedy had timing, realism and precision, this feels like a hollow, low-effort imitation that mistakes chaos for humor and noise for jokes.

War Between Land and Sea goes heavy on concept before execution. The idea itself is epicâ€”two worlds colliding, power struggles, survival, and dominationâ€”but the delivery feels uneven. Visually, it tries to be grand with battle scenes and dramatic settings, and some moments genuinely hit hard, especially when the conflict escalates.

The War Between the Land and the Sea feels less like a loud blockbuster and more like a slow, reflective story about conflict and consequences. The movie is built around the idea of humans pushing nature too far, and it uses the struggle between land and sea as a powerful symbol. From the beginning, thereâ€™s a heavy, serious tone that lets you know this isnâ€™t just about destructionâ€”itâ€™s about choices, responsibility, and what happens when balance is lost.

What really stands out is the mood. The film takes its time, using visuals and quiet moments to create tension rather than nonstop action. The contrast between the sea and the land is striking, and it often feels like nature itself is a character in the story. Some scenes hit emotionally, especially when characters are forced to face the consequences of their actions, though a few moments feel dragged out or emotionally distant.

In the end, The War Between the Land and the Sea is the kind of movie that stays with you more for its message than its plot. Itâ€™s not perfect, and it wonâ€™t appeal to everyone, especially if you prefer fast-paced stories. But if you like thoughtful films that make you reflect on humanityâ€™s relationship with nature, this one delivers a quiet, meaningful experience that lingers after the credits roll.

From the first frame, The War Between Land and Sea makes one thing clear: peace is dead. The land stands proudâ€”armies, kingdoms, steel, stone, ego. Humans build walls and call them forever. They draw borders and think nature will respect them.
The land fights back with earthquakes, collapsing cliffs, fire from beneath the ground. It roars. It resists. It bleeds. But the sea? The sea is eternal. Patient. Relentless.

This movie doesnâ€™t give comfort. It gives humility.

Final verdict:
The War Between Land and Sea is a brutal, thunderous spectacle that reminds you of one truth: humanity doesnâ€™t control natureâ€”we survive at its mercy. Loud, dark, merciless, and unforgettable. ğŸŒŠğŸ”¥âš”ï¸

The performances ground the spectacle in emotion, giving weight to the chaos unfolding on screen. Characters are driven by fear, ambition, and the instinct to survive, making their decisions feel urgent and deeply personal. The direction maintains a firm grip on tension, ensuring the conflict never loses momentum.
What sets War Between Land and Sea apart is its thematic depth. Beneath the action lies a powerful message about control, coexistence, and the cost of pushing nature beyond its limits. The film blends spectacle with meaning, turning large-scale conflict into a cautionary and compelling narrative.
By the final moments, War Between Land and Sea stands as a bold and immersive cinematic experience â€” intense, thought-provoking, and visually commanding. It earns its five-star rating as a powerful portrayal of conflict where the true enemy is imbalance itself.

War Between Land and Sea is one of those movies where peace was never really an option. From the jump, you can tell itâ€™s heading straight for chaos â€” kingdoms clashing, power struggles rising, and everybody convinced theyâ€™re right.
The story centers on a massive conflict between surface dwellers and underwater forces, each side fighting to protect what they believe belongs to them. Pride, revenge, and ancient grudges fuel the tension, turning small disagreements into full-blown war.
Visually, the movie leans hard into spectacle. Ocean battles, powerful warriors, dramatic entrances, and enough destruction to keep you glued to the screen. When the fighting starts, it doesnâ€™t hold back â€” land shakes, seas rage, and nobody escapes untouched.
What makes it fun is the scale. This isnâ€™t just personal beef; itâ€™s armies versus armies, strategy versus strength, and leaders making choices that affect entire worlds. The action is intense, the stakes are high, and the drama is loud.
It may not reinvent storytelling, but it knows its assignment: deliver epic clashes and nonstop energy.
If you enjoy large-scale battles, mythic vibes, and stories where two worlds collide with no mercy, War Between Land and Sea brings the heat from both sides.

The War Between Land and Sea is a powerful and emotionally charged movie that really makes you think. Itâ€™s not just about conflict or spectacle  itâ€™s about survival, sacrifice, and the painful consequences of division. The storytelling feels raw and intentional, and the tension between both sides keeps you deeply invested from start to finish.
One part that truly stands out is the moment when characters from both land and sea are forced to confront the cost of the war on innocent lives. That scene hits hard because it shows that no side truly wins in a battle driven by pride and misunderstanding. Itâ€™s emotional, eye-opening, and unforgettable.
If you enjoy movies that combine action with deep meaning and strong emotional moments, this film is absolutely worth watching. Itâ€™s intense, thoughtful, and leaves a lasting impression long after it ends.

Watching The War Between the Land and the Sea opened my eyes even more to how deeply broken and polluted our world has become. It reflects not only the failures within systems of power, but also the collective responsibility of humanity itself.

Yes, not all leaders are corrupt. But this crisis goes beyond government alone. From land to sea, pollution is the result of human choices our lifestyles, our consumption, and the systems we tolerate. Governments, businesses, and large corporations may be the biggest contributors, but as ordinary citizens, we are not exempt from accountability.

This series challenged me to reflect on my own role.
What choices am I making?
How can I contribute however small to healing rather than harming?

Real change will not come from a â€œ40-year planâ€ that keeps being postponed. Change must begin today in our homes, our communities, our work, and in the courage to demand better from those in power.

My hope is that governments, business leaders, and company owners will take responsibility, not just for profit, but for people and the planet. And my hope is also that we, as citizens, choose to act, speak, and live differently.

This is not just a battle between land and sea.
It is a battle for our shared future.

My heart criesâ€¦ ğŸ˜¢
But it also believes change is still possible if we start now. ğŸ’šğŸŒ

Just watched Ripley. Last episode last night. As I immediately found it gripping it couldn't be spoiled by binge watching so I thought every evening I'd watch 1 episode of "Emily in Rome" that had just come out  and then 1 episode of "Ripley". Both series are set in Italy. Well, for "Emily in Rome", after the first two episodes I slugged through..to give it a chance because I had loved "Emily in Paris"... I proceeded to FAST FORWARD all the remaining episodes so it wouldn't be recommended to me again: this took about 50 seconds. I then proceeded to savour "Ripley". From Atrani to Venice, with Rome in between, the essence of Italy was truly captured, from the locals/working class to the aristocrats/well off society people. Even all the character actors with their tiny parts were superb, the reception staff? Perfect. Signorina Buffi, (the Landlady), perfect. LUCIO THE CAT? Honestly the best performance after Andrew Scott's!

That series is way better than it has any right to be! How a spin off from a Batman movie is so damn good, I don't know, but it is. I gave the movie high marks in fact, but had no idea Colin Farrell was under all those prosthetics for the Penguin character. If he does not win many an award for that character, I'll eat my hat. The Penguin is like nothing we have seen in the past, it's very adult, dark, violent, very well written and quality series making. While I thought The Batman movie was solid (as super hero movies go...) The Penguin is a whole different level. Even if you're not into super hero genre, or Batman, etc, this is closer to The Sopranos than Batman. All of the characters are very well done, Colin Farrell, totally unrecognizable as The Penguin, is next level. Yes, in 2025, they can still make great shows if they want to. Grade A.

Just finished the show. I enjoyed it ever more than books surprisingly (read the first two). I appreciate how they kept the same sense of humor but none of the jokes were repeated (maybe one) and I think every episode had a moment that made me laugh. And I loved it so much.
Ok, at first I maybe was a little annoyed how some of the characters personalities were changed but in the second half I just accepted the show as a different version of the story and I really enjoyed it this way. The last episode made me feel more emotions then the first two books together (because the books are lighter, and I mostly was really excited while reading them but never actually worried about anything or anyone, I mean, Murderbot kinda has a plot armor, correct me if I'm wrong (but please don't spoil anything from the book three and the next ones). 
But here, I was literally on edge, because at some point, in the last episode, it gets serious and I wasn't ever sure if everyone in gonna be okay. I almost literally cried at some point, I can't imagine what I would feel if I had watched this before reading the books, not knowing anything about the plot. 
Also, Gurathin is now my absolute favourite character and I want him to be hugged and protected from all of the bad stuff. (Also the actor is absolutely nailed it, now I can't imagine anyone else as this character.)
I really hope there will be more seasons. Huge thanks to everyone who worked on the show.

No healthcare professional in their right mind would use drugs to better empathize with and or understand his patients. What sense does it make for them to compromise their clarity of mind?  All in the name of compassion? Foolish! Where are the real leaders at in the world?  Because it's becoming more â€œLord of the Flysâ€ on this doomed planet!

The Importance of Clear Thinking
When healthcare professionals take drugs or engage in any form of intoxication, even with the best intentions, they risk compromising their judgment and decision-making capabilities. Clarity of mind enables doctors to respond to emergencies, interpret medical data accurately, and execute treatment plans effectively.

Imagine a surgeon under the influence, where even a minor lapse in judgment could jeopardize a life. Or consider a therapist whose objectivity is clouded by emotional or psychological substances; they might misinterpret a patient's needs, leading them away from beneficial treatment pathways.

The trust placed in healthcare providers is immense, and it hinges on their ability to think clearly, make informed decisions, and act in the best interests of their patients. For patients, knowing their doctor is sober and focused is crucial not just for practical reasons, but also for the psychological assurance it provides.

The world keeps BLINDLY and some times willingly going down the wrong path! And this show proves it.  I'm glad it got cancelled. A doctor experimenting with drugs?! Seriously people!  This is what you want! Do you have any common sense?!

Potential Consequences of Impaired Judgement
The repercussions of a healthcare provider losing mental clarity due to substance use can range from mild to catastrophic. Subtle misjudgments in diagnosis might lead to inappropriate treatments, adversely impacting a patient's health. Moreover, the stigma attached to a doctor who uses drugsâ€”even with altruistic motivesâ€”can erode the vital trust between patients and their healthcare providers.

Empathy does not necessitate personal experience with drugs or illnesses. Instead, it can be cultivated through continued education, training, and mindfulness practices. Programs aimed at enhancing communication skills, understanding life experiences through shared narratives, and advocating for patient voices can create an environment where empathy thrives while maintaining professional integrity.

I won't get into spoilers but my general feelings of the show so far is this:
On its own its a decent supernatural mystery show. But it has nothing to do with Anne Rice. 
These don't feel like her characters, the vibes and aesthetics of the show do not carry anything over. 
It lacks the detailed macabre romanticism of Anne Rice's works, The balance between empathy and monstrousness is not there. 
And I will say the main character feels like the dumbest smart person that I have watched in years. Frustratingly so. 

I do not hate this show, but if you are an Anne Rice fan any hint of her world building or aesthetic is simply not here. The show borrows names from her books It borrows some general outlines for characters. And that's it.

8 episodes and itâ€™s already the season finale?? Thatâ€™s the problem with shows today. Even half hour comedies get 8 episodes for a â€œseasonâ€ then you wait 1-2 years for another batch of 8. This DOESNT work for sitcoms or most half hour comedies. They need to either release batches twice a year, or extend seasons closer toward 20. At least 15-16. 
Drop 10 twice a yearâ€¦ every 6-7 months for 20 a year. Thatâ€™s how you keep interest and build longevity. No one sticks around for any more than a season or 2 cuz no one wants to wait a year for a few episodes when content is always dropping. People move on and forget by time it comes around again. Most half hour comedies, especially buddy sitcoms and hang out comedies, rely on chemistry and a bond from the viewers. This doesnâ€™t happen in 8 episodesâ€¦ or 1+ year later for a batch of a few more episodes. 
This is why itâ€™s failing. Nothing sticks to long and this is why. 

It explains why broadcast sitcoms still rule even todayâ€¦ everyone likes the 20-25 episodes a season. Those with 100+ episodes in all. These will always ruleâ€¦ even in re-run.
